name: Hamamelis
description: Hamamelis, also known as Witch Hazel, is a genus of only a few species in the family Hamamelidaceae, native to Eastern Asia and North America.The genus contains deciduous shrubs and small trees, growing up to 8 m (26 ft) tall. This plant produces simple oval leaves and spider-like flowers arranged in clusters. Flowers have spicy fragrance and are borne on bare stems from autumn to early spring. Hamamelis is extremely frost resistant, subtle in color and very delicate in form, adding interest to the winter garden.
meaning: The scientific name is made up of Greek words “hama”, which means “at same time” or “together” and “mêlon”, meaning “apple” or “fruit”, since the plant can bear flowers and fruits at the same time. Its common name “Witch Hazel” is partly due to the resemblance of its leaves to the common hazel and partly from the Middle English “wiche” (from the Old English “wice”), meaning “pliant” or “bendable” and relates to its twigs and young branches.
color_description: Hamamelis flowers range in color from deep red to yellow.
